awd_titl_txt: REU Site: SUNFEST - Summer Undergraduate Research in Sensor Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This three year renewal Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site Program, SUNFEST: Summer Undergraduate Research in Sensor Technologies, at the University of Pennsylvania, will offer a diverse cohort of undergraduate students the opportunity to work on research projects involving sensor technologies with the goal to develop new materials and devices. By working on a meaningful research project of their own in a dynamic and supportive environment, students will contribute to academically-based discovery that will lead to better devices and systems for medical, robotics, communications, environmental, energy, agricultural and surveillance applications. Each of these projects deals with a scientifically important topic for advancing the understanding of a specific sensor phenomenon that have "real-life" applications. An important focus of this REU will be to extend these research experiences to students at small, four-year colleges where research experiences are less abundant and to engage students who come from groups traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering, including first generation, low income, underrepresented minority students and women.

Over 10 summer weeks, the University of Pennsylvania will host 10 undergraduate students who will be involved in high quality, cutting-edge research projects related to sensor technology. Research projects will include sensor phenomena, materials, nano- and micro-fabricated sensors, sensing using quantum systems and sensor applications in medicine, agriculture and robotics. To foster students' development as future researchers, they will participate in weekly group meetings and seminars in their labs. In addition, the REU offers professional development activities for the student participants, include workshops on writing proposals and technical reports, responsible conduct of research, applying to graduate school, and effective oral presentations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The SUNFEST Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) Program has supported 31 research projects that pushed the frontier of scientific knowledge in the field of sensor technology while simultaneously engaging, inspiring and instructing a diverse group of undergraduate scholars regarding the research enterprise.

Intellectual Merit:  SUNFEST research projects developed sensors for a range of applications, including robotics, cancer detection, grasping systems, electronic display screens, and water/nitrate detection for agriculture. To date, four journal publications, two refereed proceedings and three presentations at national meetings resulted from the program.

Broader Impact:  In addition to the impact of the scientific contributions to the well-being of society, SUNSET research provided a platform to excite, engage and educate undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds, connecting engineering and science fundamentals to sensor technology though active learning, research experiences and professional workshops.  During the three years of the program (a cohort of 31 students), 19% of the REU participants identified as African-American, 10% as Hispanic-American, 45% as Asian-American 3% as Caribbean American, and 39% as White.  In addition, 48% were female, 48% were male and 3% were non-binary or gender non-conforming, and 26% came from non-R1 undergraduate institutions.  70% of the participants who have graduated from their undergraduate programs are now pursuing advanced degrees in STEM fields.  These findings demonstrate the success of the SUNFEST program in recruiting and providing research opportunities to students of all backgrounds/experience levels to help diversify the engineering research community.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/06/2024
Modified by: Sue A Bidstrup-Allen
